prompt:
INDEX PRODUCT PATTERN ANALYSIS

OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll now produce my answer accordingly in plain text.</think>One acceptable way to “read” the pattern was to try writing each key number kₙ in the form

  kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n)

and then ask: when is f(n) an integer? (In other words, can we “absorb” the index n into a multiplier?) One may check that for some keys this works out exactly while for others it does not.

For example, suppose you have

 • k₇ = 76. Dividing by 7 gives
  76/7 ≈ 10.8571  or, if you use integer division, 10 with a remainder of 6.
So one may write
  76 = (76/7)·7 + 0  (or equivalently 76 = 10·7 + 6).

 • k₈ = 224. Here 224/8 = 28 exactly so that
  224 = 28·8 + 0.
Thus f(8) = 28.

 • k₉ = 467. Dividing by 9 gives
  467/9 ≈ 51.8889, i.e. 9×51 = 459 with a remainder of 8.
So one may write
  467 = (467/9)·9 + 0  (or 467 = 51·9 + 8).

 • k₁₁ = 1155. Since 1155/11 = 105 exactly,
  1155 = 105·11 + 0.
Thus f(11) = 105.

 • k₁₂ is given (or can be checked) to equal 2683. Dividing by 12 gives
  2683/12 ≈ 223.5833, that is 12×223 = 2676 with a remainder of 7.
So one may write
  2683 = (2683/12)·12 + 0  (or 2683 = 223·12 + 7).

An alternative way to state the answer is as follows:

 For each key we have

  k₇ = 76  = (76⁄7)·7      or, using integer division, 10×7 + 6.
  k₈ = 224  = 28×8        so f(8) = 28.
  k₉ = 467  = (467⁄9)·9    or, using integer division, 51×9 + 8.
  k₁₁ = 1155 = 105×11    so f(11) = 105.
  k₁₂ = 2683 = (2683⁄12)·12 or, by integer division, 223×12 + 7.

Notice that for k₈ and k₁₁ the number factors exactly as an integer times n. In our “pattern‐analysis” this is what one may call a special case where the index appears as a multiplier (that is, f(n) is an integer).

Any answer equivalent to the above – stating for each key either

 f(7)=76⁄7 (≈10.8571), f(8)=28, f(9)=467⁄9 (≈51.8889), f(11)=105, f(12)=2683⁄12 (≈223.5833)

or else giving the quotient–remainder form – is correct.

To summarize, one acceptable answer is:

 • k₇ = 76 = (76⁄7)·7    (or 10×7 + 6)
 • k₈ = 224 = 28×8      (so f(8)=28)
 • k₉ = 467 = (467⁄9)·9   (or 51×9 + 8)
 • k₁₁ = 1155 = 105×11   (so f(11)=105)
 • k₁₂ = 2683 = (2683⁄12)·12  (or 223×12 + 7)

This is one acceptable “solution” to the problem.
